pullRequest.body:
Moves:
- `multiplicity_addValuation` -> `AddValuation.multiplicity`
- `multiplicity_addValuation_apply` -> `AddValuation.multiplicity_apply`

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

Current commit [fb3d4daa1c](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/fb3d4daa1c705d4bfbf37bd061aff1f611ae47a6)

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
Thanks for requesting my review. I added the multiplicity file a long time ago so I'm a bit out of date, and I'm taking a step back from reviewing so I don't have anything to say.

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#19149~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#18786~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#19122~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#18954~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

> In general, Mathlib prefers using multiplicative valuation rather than additive ones, and most of the theory is developed for those. Is there a specific reason why you want to work with (and improve) `addVal`? The reason why we ended up chosing one of the two was to avoid a lot of code duplication, when possible, and there is no advantage of using additive rather than multiplicative valuations, beyond a psychological one, I believe. But perhaps you have something else in sight.

This is mostly psychological, but it's also to match [padicValRat](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/NumberTheory/Padics/PadicVal/Basic.html#padicValRat) and the general convention for p-adic valuation, and it's annoying to use `Multiplicative.ofAdd` everywhere.
Don't `@[to_additive]` and `AddValuation.ofValuation`/`AddValuation.toValuation` mostly resolve the problem of duplication?

> > In general, Mathlib prefers using multiplicative valuation rather than additive ones, and most of the theory is developed for those. Is there a specific reason why you want to work with (and improve) `addVal`? The reason why we ended up chosing one of the two was to avoid a lot of code duplication, when possible, and there is no advantage of using additive rather than multiplicative valuations, beyond a psychological one, I believe. But perhaps you have something else in sight.
> 
> This is mostly psychological, but it's also to match [padicValRat](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/NumberTheory/Padics/PadicVal/Basic.html#padicValRat) and the general convention for p-adic valuation, and it's annoying to use `Multiplicative.ofAdd` everywhere. Don't `@[to_additive]` and `AddValuation.ofValuation`/`AddValuation.toValuation` mostly resolve the problem of duplication?

I understand. My feeling is that we should avoid having two different approaches to valuations, becuse this would make the library harder to maintain. On the long run, I would even suggest that we get rid of the additive p-adic valuation, but that's another point. At any rate, are you sure that `@to_additive` really plays well with valuations, expecially given that they are valued in `StuffWithZero`?

In general, Mathlib prefers using multiplicative valuation rather than additive ones, and most of the theory is developed for those. Is there a specific reason why you want to work with (and improve) `addVal`? The reason why we ended up chosing one of the two was to avoid a lot of code duplication, when possible, and there is no advantage of using additive rather than multiplicative valuations, beyond a psychological one, I believe. But perhaps you have something else in sight.

Everything looks okay at first glance, but I have not touched this part of the library much either. In particular I have no idea if the proofs towards the end could be optimized. Does @faenuccio or @pechersky want to take a final look?

Everything looks okay at first glance, but I have not touched this part of the library much either. In particular I have no idea if the proofs towards the end could be optimized. Does @faenuccio or @pechersky want to take a final look?

In general, Mathlib prefers using multiplicative valuation rather than additive ones, and most of the theory is developed for those. Is there a specific reason why you want to work with (and improve) `addVal`? The reason why we ended up chosing one of the two was to avoid a lot of code duplication, when possible, and there is no advantage of using additive rather than multiplicative valuations, beyond a psychological one, I believe. But perhaps you have something else in sight.

Should this maybe be made `protected` since I can imagine we'd want to talk about the original `multiplicity` definition too?
```suggestion
noncomputable protected def multiplicity (hp : Prime p) : AddValuation R â„•âˆž :=
```
Good idea, done
I am not sure to understand why we want to add this lemma that seems only a special case of `WithTop.map_eq_one_iff` (and likewise for the one below).

Following [this poll](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/Defeq.20abuse.20with.20ENat/near/482110206), all `WithTop.map` functions have to be copied over to `ENat.map` if you want to use them
Why do we want to `protect` this `def`? The name seems specific enough, no? (same question for the `def` below).
There is a problem if you open, e.g., both `OneHom` and `ZeroHom` at the same time

pullRequest.title: feat(RingTheory/Valuation/PrimeMultiplicity): define `WithTop â„¤`-valued prime multiplicity on a fraction field

source.title: feat: Multiplicity and prime-adic valuation of derivations

nodes.body: Thanks for requesting my review. I added the multiplicity file a long time ago so I'm a bit out of date, and I'm taking a step back from reviewing so I don't have anything to say.

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#19149~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#18786~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#19122~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#18954~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

Everything looks okay at first glance, but I have not touched this part of the library much either. In particular I have no idea if the proofs towards the end could be optimized. Does @faenuccio or @pechersky want to take a final look?

In general, Mathlib prefers using multiplicative valuation rather than additive ones, and most of the theory is developed for those. Is there a specific reason why you want to work with (and improve) `addVal`? The reason why we ended up chosing one of the two was to avoid a lot of code duplication, when possible, and there is no advantage of using additive rather than multiplicative valuations, beyond a psychological one, I believe. But perhaps you have something else in sight.

> In general, Mathlib prefers using multiplicative valuation rather than additive ones, and most of the theory is developed for those. Is there a specific reason why you want to work with (and improve) `addVal`? The reason why we ended up chosing one of the two was to avoid a lot of code duplication, when possible, and there is no advantage of using additive rather than multiplicative valuations, beyond a psychological one, I believe. But perhaps you have something else in sight.

This is mostly psychological, but it's also to match [padicValRat](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/NumberTheory/Padics/PadicVal/Basic.html#padicValRat) and the general convention for p-adic valuation, and it's annoying to use `Multiplicative.ofAdd` everywhere.
Don't `@[to_additive]` and `AddValuation.ofValuation`/`AddValuation.toValuation` mostly resolve the problem of duplication?

> > In general, Mathlib prefers using multiplicative valuation rather than additive ones, and most of the theory is developed for those. Is there a specific reason why you want to work with (and improve) `addVal`? The reason why we ended up chosing one of the two was to avoid a lot of code duplication, when possible, and there is no advantage of using additive rather than multiplicative valuations, beyond a psychological one, I believe. But perhaps you have something else in sight.
> 
> This is mostly psychological, but it's also to match [padicValRat](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/NumberTheory/Padics/PadicVal/Basic.html#padicValRat) and the general convention for p-adic valuation, and it's annoying to use `Multiplicative.ofAdd` everywhere. Don't `@[to_additive]` and `AddValuation.ofValuation`/`AddValuation.toValuation` mostly resolve the problem of duplication?

I understand. My feeling is that we should avoid having two different approaches to valuations, becuse this would make the library harder to maintain. On the long run, I would even suggest that we get rid of the additive p-adic valuation, but that's another point. At any rate, are you sure that `@to_additive` really plays well with valuations, expecially given that they are valued in `StuffWithZero`?
